veg_detail: Site is a small burnt forest mire with sedges, Sphagnum moss, and open water pools. Fire has removed some vegetation and Polytrichum has colonised
disturbance: Site burned four years ago in 2017 due to forest fire
flux_method_description: Using eosAC autochamber. Dark chamber measurement

Pine-dwarf shrub bog: Sphagnum ridges with Pinus sylvestris, Ledum palustris, Chamaedaphne calyculata, Sphagnum fuscum. The pine height is
usually 0.5–2.0 m and 3–10% cover.

landform: (forested bog) with undulating microrelief: hummock peat about 30cm height, space between hummocks and lawn

veg_detail: Dry graminoid
landform: Well-developed high-centre, flat- centre and low-centre polygons
flux_method_description: PVC collars (height 15 cm 9 diameter 20 cm). The UGGA was used to measure both CH4 and CO2 concentrations using a closed system with a 1 Hz sampling rate. The chamber was left in place for two minutes to achieve a stable increase in CH4 and CO2 concentration within the chamber headspace. NEE was measured with transparent chamber and ER was measured with opaque chamber (hood) that is used to calculate GPP (GPP = NEE + ER)
soil_type_detail: Soils within the Barrow field sites are classified as Gelisols with three suborders (Turbels, 77%, Orthels, 8.7% and organic soils, 1% underlain by permafrost) within 100 cm of the surface

The chamber was left in place for two minutes to achieve a stable increase in CH4 and CO2 concentration within the chamber headspace. NEE was measured with transparent chamber and ER was measured with opaque chamber (hood) that is used to calculate GPP (GPP = NEE + ER)
soil_type_detail: Soils within the Barrow field sites are classified as Gelisols with three suborders (Turbels, 77%, Orthels, 8.7% and organic soils, 1% underlain by permafrost) within 100 cm of the surface

veg_detail: This treed fen is dominated by Larix laricina (Du Roi) K.Koch, Picea mariana (Mill.) Britton, Betula pumila (L.), Equisetum fluviatile (L.), Smilacina trifolia (L.) Sloboda, Carex spp., and Sphagnum fuscum (Schimp.) Klinggr and brown mosses, largely Tomenthypnum nitens (Hedwig) Loeske
flux_method_description: A cylindrical opaque chamber (20 cm × 50 cm) was placed on the collar, with water poured around the collar edge to create a seal. A battery-powered fan was used to mix the chamber headspace. A thermocouple located within the chamber, attached to a thermometer, was used to measure temperature during sampling. A 20 mL syringe was used to collect gas samples at intervals of 7, 15, 25, and 35 min following chamber closure and injected into Exetainers (Labco, UK). A gas chromatograph with a flame ionization detector (250 ◦ C), helium gas carrier, and standards of 5 and 50 ppm was used to determine CH4 concentration

veg_detail: Treed bog Lichen/Rhododendron
disturbance: Seismic lines- approximately 3 m wide and run both north to south and east to west
flux_method_description: A clear acrylic chamber (60 × 60 × 30 cm) was placed on a stainless-steel collar (60 × 60 cm).The concentration of CO2 (ppm) was determined inside the chamber at 15 s intervals for a maximum of 2.5 min. The linear change in CO2 concentration over time was used to calcu- late net ecosystem exchange (NEE; g CO2 m2 d−1). Ecosystem respiration (ER; g CO2 m2 d−1) was determined by darkening the chamber with an opaque cloth shroud. Gross primary production (GPP; g CO2 m2 d−1) was calculated as the difference between NEE and ER.

citation_co2: CO2: Torbern Tagesson et al. (2012) High-resolution satellite data reveal an increase in peak growing season gross primary production in a high-Arctic wet tundra ecosystem 1992-2008. (2013) Modelling of growing season methane fluxes in a high-Arctic wet tundra ecosystem 1997–2010 using in situ and high-resolution satellite data, Tellus B: Chemical and Physical Meteorology, 65:1, DOI: 10.3402/tellusb.v65i0.19722
citation_ch4: CO2: Torbern Tagesson et al. (2012) High-resolution satellite data reveal an increase in peak growing season gross primary production in a high-Arctic wet tundra ecosystem 1992-2008. veg_detail: High-Arctic heterogeneous wetland area. It is a patterned fen characterized by alternating high, dry heath areas, and low, wet fen areas
flux_method_description: The chamber was a transparent Plexiglas cube of 0.3 m height and a ground area of 0.34 m2. The outlet and inlet for gases were located on one of the chamber sides, 0.15 and 0.25 m above the ground, respectively. Two small fans were located in the upper part of the chamber to ensure proper mixing of the chamber headspace and representative sampling

(2013) Modelling of growing season methane fluxes in a high-Arctic wet tundra ecosystem 1997–2010 using in situ and high-resolution satellite data, Tellus B: Chemical and Physical Meteorology, 65:1, DOI: 10.3402/tellusb.v65i0.19722
citation_ch4: CO2: Torbern Tagesson et al. (2012) High-resolution satellite data reveal an increase in peak growing season gross primary production in a high-Arctic wet tundra ecosystem 1992-2008. veg_detail: High-Arctic heterogeneous wetland area. It is a patterned fen characterized by alternating high, dry heath areas, and low, wet fen areas
flux_method_description: The chamber was a transparent Plexiglas cube of 0.3 m height and a ground area of 0.34 m2. The outlet and inlet for gases were located on one of the chamber sides, 0.15 and 0.25 m above the ground, respectively. Two small fans were located in the upper part of the chamber to ensure proper mixing of the chamber headspace and representative sampling

site_name: Council Road Mile Marker 71, Seward Peninsula
data_contributor_or_author: Oriana Chafe, Ian Shirley, Stan Wullschleger, and Margaret Torn
citation_co2: Oriana Chafe, Ian Shirley, Stan Wullschleger, and Margaret chafe. 2023. Soil CO2 and CH4 Chamber Fluxes in Tussock Tundra, Council Road Mile Marker 71, Seward Peninsula, Alaska, 2016-2019. Next Generation Ecosystem Experiments Arctic Data Collection, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tennessee, USA. Dataset accessed on 11/20/2023 at https://doi.org/10.5440/1765733.
citation_ch4: Oriana Chafe, Ian Shirley, Stan Wullschleger, and Margaret chafe. 2023. Soil CO2 and CH4 Chamber Fluxes in Tussock Tundra, Council Road Mile Marker 71, Seward Peninsula, Alaska, 2016-2019. Next Generation Ecosystem Experiments Arctic Data Collection, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tennessee, USA. Dataset accessed on 11/20/2023 at https://doi.org/10.5440/1765733.
veg_detail: NA
flux_method_description: Chambers (25 cm diameter, 15-20 cm height) were tall enough to enclose vegetation and were vented according to Xu et al. (2006), to minimize pressure excursions due to the Venturi effect. In all plots, chambers were seated on PVC bases extending ~15 cm below the soil surface. For each flux measurement, the chamber was seated in a 3 cm-deep, water-filled trench in the base's top rim to create an airtight seal.

veg_detail: NA
flux_method_description: Chambers (25 cm diameter, 15-20 cm height) were tall enough to enclose vegetation and were vented according to Xu et al. (2006), to minimize pressure excursions due to the Venturi effect. In all plots, chambers were seated on PVC bases extending ~15 cm below the soil surface. For each flux measurement, the chamber was seated in a 3 cm-deep, water-filled trench in the base's top rim to create an airtight seal.

citation_co2: Oriana Chafe, Ian Shirley, Stan Wullschleger, and Margaret chafe. 2023. Soil CO2 and CH4 Chamber Fluxes in Tussock Tundra, Council Road Mile Marker 71, Seward Peninsula, Alaska, 2016-2019. Dataset accessed on 11/20/2023 at https://doi.org/10.5440/1765733.
citation_ch4: Oriana Chafe, Ian Shirley, Stan Wullschleger, and Margaret chafe. 2023. Soil CO2 and CH4 Chamber Fluxes in Tussock Tundra, Council Road Mile Marker 71, Seward Peninsula, Alaska, 2016-2019. Dataset accessed on 11/20/2023 at https://doi.org/10.5440/1765733.
veg_detail: NA
flux_method_description: Chambers (25 cm diameter, 15-20 cm height) were tall enough to enclose vegetation and were vented according to Xu et al. (2006), to minimize pressure excursions due to the Venturi effect. In all plots, chambers were seated on PVC bases extending ~15 cm below the soil surface. For each flux measurement, the chamber was seated in a 3 cm-deep, water-filled trench in the base's top rim to create an airtight seal.

The mesic/moist palsa vegetation type. If sometime more grassy, sometimes moss rich in S fuscum or E nigrum. This vegetation type remains on palsas that has recently collapsed but tend to have greater moisture content after the collapse has occurred.

citation_ch4: Voigt, C., Virkkala, A.-M., Hould Gosselin, G., Bennett, K.A., Black, T.A., Chevrier-Dion, C., Guggenberger, G., Hashmi, W., Kou, D., Marquis, C., Marsh, P., Marushchak, M.E., Nesic, Z., Nykänen, H., Saarela, T., Sauheitl, L., Walker, B., Weiss, N., Wilcox, E.J., Sonnentag, O. (2023). Arctic soil methane sink stimulated by plant respiration and dry conditions. Nature Climate Change 13, pp. 1095-1104. DOI: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3.
veg_detail: Note: I would classify this as mesic tundra. If this option does not exist, probably wetland. The water table during summer is periodically low, and the dominant vegetation at PC is a thick lichen layer and not typical wetland vegetation. These are degrading, high-centered polygons, so the polygon centers are dry compared to commonly studied polygonal tundra
flux_method_description: chamber volume 17 L, deployment time 5min (of this only 90s used for flux calculation of CO2 and 90-300s for calculation of CH4 fluxes. Tubing length ca. 2m. Transparent chamber; for measurements of Reco, chamber was covered with an opaque cover. For details see the associated publication (Voigt et al 2023 Nature Climate Change, doi: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3)
soil_type_detail: organic soil consisting of poorly decomposed sphagnum mosses

citation_ch4: Voigt, C., Virkkala, A.-M., Hould Gosselin, G., Bennett, K.A., Black, T.A., Chevrier-Dion, C., Guggenberger, G., Hashmi, W., Kou, D., Marquis, C., Marsh, P., Marushchak, M.E., Nesic, Z., Nykänen, H., Saarela, T., Sauheitl, L., Walker, B., Weiss, N., Wilcox, E.J., Sonnentag, O. (2023). Arctic soil methane sink stimulated by plant respiration and dry conditions. Nature Climate Change 13, pp. 1095-1104. DOI: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3.
veg_detail: Note: I would classify this as mesic tundra. If this option does not exist, probably wetland. The polygon rims are elevated by ca. 10-30 cm and therefore dry. The only vegetation on the polygon rims (PR) are lichen. No wetland vegetation is present.
flux_method_description: chamber volume 17 L, deployment time 5min (of this only 90s used for flux calculation of CO2 and 90-300s for calculation of CH4 fluxes. Tubing length ca. 2m. Transparent chamber; for measurements of Reco, chamber was covered with an opaque cover. For details see the associated publication (Voigt et al 2023 Nature Climate Change, doi: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3)
soil_type_detail: organic soil consisting of poorly decomposed sphagnum mosses

citation_ch4: Voigt, C., Virkkala, A.-M., Hould Gosselin, G., Bennett, K.A., Black, T.A., Chevrier-Dion, C., Guggenberger, G., Hashmi, W., Kou, D., Marquis, C., Marsh, P., Marushchak, M.E., Nesic, Z., Nykänen, H., Saarela, T., Sauheitl, L., Walker, B., Weiss, N., Wilcox, E.J., Sonnentag, O. (2023). Arctic soil methane sink stimulated by plant respiration and dry conditions. Nature Climate Change 13, pp. 1095-1104. DOI: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3.
veg_detail: The dominant vegetation in the polygon troughs are sphagnum mosses. The troughs can be wet in spring and autumn, but in most of the summer the water table is below the surface, explaining the low CH4 fluxes. These are degrading high-centered polygons and therefore dry compared to other polygonal tundra areas.
flux_method_description: chamber volume 17 L, deployment time 5min (of this only 90s used for flux calculation of CO2 and 90-300s for calculation of CH4 fluxes. Tubing length ca. 2m. Transparent chamber; for measurements of Reco, chamber was covered with an opaque cover. For details see the associated publication (Voigt et al 2023 Nature Climate Change, doi: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3)
soil_type_detail: organic soil consisting of poorly decomposed sphagnum mosses

veg_detail: Patches of lichen (TL) are interspersed with the dwarf shrub tundra (TS). The lichen layer (for example Alectoria ochroleuca, Cladonia sp., Gowardia sp., Flavocetraria sp.) is well-developed and 2-6cm thick.
landform: upland mineral tundra on continuous permafrost
site_representativeness: This is difficult to answer: this is one of several vegetation classes measured within upland tundra. Upland tundra is the dominant landcover type in the region.
flux_method_description: chamber volume 17 L, deployment time 5min (of this only 90s used for flux calculation of CO2 and 90-300s for calculation of CH4 fluxes. Tubing length ca. 2m. Transparent chamber; for measurements of Reco, chamber was covered with an opaque cover. For details see the associated publication (Voigt et al 2023 Nature Climate Change, doi: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3)
soil_type_detail: mineral soil with thin organic layer

veg_detail: This is the dominant tundra vegetation type at Trail Valley Creek. Most of the landscape (59 %) is classified as low or erect dwarf-shrub tundra (class S1 and S2), where the measurement location TS falls under S1 (dwarf shrubs). In this well-drained shrub tundra area the dominant vegetation types are deciduous shrubs such as dwarf birch (Betula nana subsp. glandulosa), labrador tea (Ledum palustre L.), herbaceous species such as mountain cranberry (Vaccinium vitis-idaea L.), bearberry (Arctostaphylos uva-ursi L.), bilberry (Vaccinium uliginosum L.), crowberry (Empetrum nigrum L.), forbs and bryophytes.
landform: upland mineral tundra on continuous permafrost
site_representativeness: This is difficult to answer: this is one of several vegetation classes measured within upland tundra. Upland tundra is the dominant landcover type in the region.
flux_method_description: chamber volume 17 L, deployment time 5min (of this only 90s used for flux calculation of CO2 and 90-300s for calculation of CH4 fluxes. Tubing length ca. 2m. Transparent chamber; for measurements of Reco, chamber was covered with an opaque cover. For details see the associated publication (Voigt et al 2023 Nature Climate Change, doi: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3)
soil_type_detail: mineral soil where organic layer is typically thin and only thicker under shrubs

citation_ch4: Voigt, C., Virkkala, A.-M., Hould Gosselin, G., Bennett, K.A., Black, T.A., Chevrier-Dion, C., Guggenberger, G., Hashmi, W., Kou, D., Marquis, C., Marsh, P., Marushchak, M.E., Nesic, Z., Nykänen, H., Saarela, T., Sauheitl, L., Walker, B., Weiss, N., Wilcox, E.J., Sonnentag, O. (2023). Arctic soil methane sink stimulated by plant respiration and dry conditions. Nature Climate Change 13, pp. 1095-1104. DOI: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3.
veg_detail: Tussocks (Eriophorum sp.) occur within the dwarf shrub tundra. All the 3 measurement locations (TL, TS, TT) occur at small scales (within >1m of each other) in this heterogeneous upland tundra measurement location.
landform: upland mineral tundra on continuous permafrost
site_representativeness: This is difficult to answer: this is one of several vegetation classes measured within upland tundra. Upland tundra is the dominant landcover type in the region.
flux_method_description: chamber volume 30 L, closure time 2-3 minutes (of this, less than 60s used for flux calculation. Tubing length 35 m. Transparent and opaque chambers were used and measurements of transparent and dark were done on different collars, so some spatial variability is introduced. For details see the associated publication (Voigt et al 2023 Nature Climate Change, doi: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3)
soil_type_detail: mineral soil with very variable organic layer thickness.

landform: upland mineral tundra on continuous permafrost
site_representativeness: This is difficult to answer: this is one of several vegetation classes measured within upland tundra. Upland tundra is the dominant landcover type in the region.

For details see the associated publication (Voigt et al 2023 Nature Climate Change, doi: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3)

citation_ch4: Voigt, C., Virkkala, A.-M., Hould Gosselin, G., Bennett, K.A., Black, T.A., Chevrier-Dion, C., Guggenberger, G., Hashmi, W., Kou, D., Marquis, C., Marsh, P., Marushchak, M.E., Nesic, Z., Nykänen, H., Saarela, T., Sauheitl, L., Walker, B., Weiss, N., Wilcox, E.J., Sonnentag, O. (2023). Arctic soil methane sink stimulated by plant respiration and dry conditions. Nature Climate Change 13, pp. 1095-1104. DOI: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3.
veg_detail: degrading polygon edge that is affected by thermokarst and located on the shore of a thermokarst lake. The dominant vegetation are spaghnum mosses and sedges (Sphagnum spp, Carex sp). The shrub species Comarum palustre also occurs.
flux_method_description: chamber volume 17 L, deployment time 5min (of this only 90s used for flux calculation of CO2 and 90-300s for calculation of CH4 fluxes. Tubing length ca. 2m. Transparent chamber; for measurements of Reco, chamber was covered with an opaque cover. For details see the associated publication (Voigt et al 2023 Nature Climate Change, doi: 10.1038/s41558-023-01785-3)
soil_type_detail: organic soil consisting of poorly decomposed sphagnum mosses

The vascular plant community of
the mire consists mainly of Eriophorum vaginatum L., Trichophorum
cespitosum L. Hartm., Vaccinium oxycoccos L.,
Andromeda polifolia L., and Rubus chamaemorus L.
Sphagnum majus Russ. C. Jens is found on the bottom of the
carpets while Sphagnum balticum Russ. C. Jens dominates
the lawn. The hummocks are dominated by Sphagnum fuscum
Schimp. Klinggr. (Laine et al 2012, Nilsson et al 2008). Total
(moss + vascular plants) aboveground biomass is 141 ± 45
gm–2 (Laine et al 2012).

The vascular plant community of
the mire consists mainly of Eriophorum vaginatum L., Trichophorum
cespitosum L. Hartm., Vaccinium oxycoccos L.,
Andromeda polifolia L., and Rubus chamaemorus L.
Sphagnum majus Russ. C. Jens is found on the bottom of the
carpets while Sphagnum balticum Russ. C. Jens dominates
the lawn. The hummocks are dominated by Sphagnum fuscum
Schimp. Klinggr. (Laine et al 2012, Nilsson et al 2008). Total
(moss + vascular plants) aboveground biomass is 141 ± 45
gm–2 (Laine et al 2012).

citation_ch4: Korrensalo, A., Männistö, E., Alekseychik, P., Mammarella, I., Rinne, J., Vesala, T., and Tuittila, E.-S. (2018). Small spatial variability in methane emission measured from a wet patterned boreal bog. Biogeosciences, 15, 1749–1761. 10.5194/bg-15-1749-2018.
veg_detail: NA
landform: Measurement plots cover the microtopographical variation of different plant community types in the site: HHU = high hummock, HU = hummock, HL = high lawn, L = lawn, HO = hollow, MB = "mud bottom"/ bare peat surface.
flux_method_description: Aluminium collars 60 x 60 cm (surface area 3600 cm2) in each measurement plot. For a measurement, an opaque aluminium chamber (height 36.3 cm) was placed in the groove on top of the collar, and water poured into the groove to make the chamber airtight. Chamber closure 35 minutes per measurement. In the flux calculation chamber height was corrected according to the surface topography for each measurement plot.

veg_detail: NA
landform: Measurement plots cover the microtopographical variation of different plant community types in the site: HHU = high hummock, HU = hummock, HL = high lawn, L = lawn, HO = hollow, MB = "mud bottom"/ bare peat surface.
flux_method_description: Aluminium collars 60 x 60 cm in each measurement plot. For a measurement, a transparent plexiglass chamber (56 x 56 x 30 cm) was placed in the groove on top of the collar, and water poured into the groove to make the chamber airtight. Measurement time 90-180 sec.

flux_method_description: Aluminium collars 60 x 60 cm in each measurement plot. For a measurement, a transparent plexiglass chamber (56 x 56 x 30 cm) was placed in the groove on top of the collar, and water poured into the groove to make the chamber airtight. Measurement time 90-180 sec.

flux_method_description: Aluminium collars 60 x 60 cm in each measurement plot. For a measurement, a hooded dark chamber (56 x 56 x 30 cm) was placed in the groove on top of the collar, and water poured into the groove to make the chamber airtight. Measurement time 90-180 sec.

citation_co2: Korrensalo, A., Mehtätalo, L., Alekseychik, P., Uljas, S., Mammarella, I., Vesala, T., and Tuittila, E.-S. (2020). Varying vegetation composition, respiration and photosynthesis decrease temporal variability of the CO2 sink in a boreal bog. Ecosystems, 23, 842–858. 10.1007/s10021-019-00434-1. / Korrensalo, Aino; Tuittila, Eeva-Stiina; Uljas, Salli (2019): Closed chamber measurements of net ecosystem exchange of CO2 from Siikaneva bog, Finland. PANGAEA, https://doi.org/10.1594/PANGAEA.905575.

Bret-Harte, G. Grosse, M. Langer, J. Nitzbon. Dry Yedoma upland taliks as an unpredicted source of atmospheric methane. Submitted, Nature Communications.
veg_detail: Graminoid: Vegetation is grassland succession following disturbance of the boreal (spruce) forest
flux_method_detail: Chambers consisted of opaque, plastic 20-L buckets with bottoms removed and resealable air-tight lids (Gamma Seal Lid, Encore Plastics, Sandusky, OH, USA) Chambers blocked 88% (41%) of photosynthetically active radiation measured with a cosign quantum flux sensor (Apogee Instruments, Logan, UT) in full sun (shade).
stock_depth: 700 cm (7-m deep talik) top of permafrost at 7m in borehole/soil core; mean dry bulk density 1.21 g cm-3, mean OC = 1.21%

flux_method_detail: Chambers consisted of opaque, plastic 20-L buckets with bottoms removed and resealable air-tight lids (Gamma Seal Lid, Encore Plastics, Sandusky, OH, USA) Chambers blocked 88% (41%) of photosynthetically active radiation measured with a cosign quantum flux sensor (Apogee Instruments, Logan, UT) in full sun (shade).

citation_co2: Nykänen, H., Heikkinen, J. E. P., Pirinen, L., Tiilikainen, K., and Martikainen, P. J.: Annual CO2 exchange and CH4 fluxes on a subarctic palsa mire during climatically different years, Global Biogeochem. Cy., 17, 2003.
veg_detail: Sphagnum lindbergii, Sphagnum riparium most common vascular plants were Eriophorum angustifolium, Eriophorum russeolum, Vaccnium microcarpum and Carex limosa.
flux_method_description: The transparent closed chamber was made of 1.6mm polycarbonate (60 cm x 60 cm x 25 cm). The CO2 concentration in the chamber was measured with a portable infrared gas analyzer (Li-6200 Portable Photosynthesis System, LI- COR, inc., Lincoln, Nebraska, USA) during an interval of 90 to 120 s and was equipped with a pump circulating all sample air (1.3 L min1)

citation_co2: Nykänen, H., Heikkinen, J. E. P., Pirinen, L., Tiilikainen, K., and Martikainen, P. J.: Annual CO2 exchange and CH4 fluxes on a subarctic palsa mire during climatically different years, Global Biogeochem. Cy., 17, 2003.
veg_detail: Sphagnum lindbergii, Sphagnum riparium most common vascular plants were Eriophorum angustifolium, Eriophorum russeolum, Vaccnium microcarpum and Carex limosa.

data_contributor_or_author: Hailey Webb, Merritt Turetsky, Catherine Dieleman, Evan Kane
land_cover: Tree cover, needleleaved, evergreen, closed to open (>15%)
veg_detail: NA
flux_method_description: Chamber volume = 227000 cm3, Ground area 3620 cm2. In 2021 and earlier, all methane fluxes were completed using gas samples captured in syringes and then processed on a GC within 48 hours of collection and CO2 fluxes were collected using EGM-4 units paired with PAR and tempreature sensors (collection time = ~2 minutes) . Starting in 2022, we started using a Picarro Gas Scouter with a sampling time of 2 minutes (CO2 and CH4 were measured simultaneously within those 2 minutes).

flux_method_description: 8200-01S from LI-COR (volume = 4244.1 cm3, area = 317.8 cm2, tubing length = 2 m). Deployment time = 300 sec and Hutchinson-Mosier (1981) flux estimation

citation_ch4: St. Pierre, K, Danielsen, B., Hermesdorf, L., D'Imperio, L., Iversen, L., Elberling, B. (2019) Drivers of net methane uptake across Greenlandic dry heath tundra landscapes. Soil Biology and Biochemistry, 138, 107605. 10.1016/j.soilbio.2019.107605
veg_detail: Shrub cover with secondary complete cover of lichens and mosses. Dominant plants include Carex capillaris and Thalictrum alpinum with patches of Silene acaulis and Juncus tridus.
flux_method_description: Plots of 1 x 1 m with 0.0445 m^2 aluminum frame.

citation_ch4: St. Pierre, K, Danielsen, B., Hermesdorf, L., D'Imperio, L., Iversen, L., Elberling, B. (2019) Drivers of net methane uptake across Greenlandic dry heath tundra landscapes. Soil Biology and Biochemistry, 138, 107605. 10.1016/j.soilbio.2019.107605
veg_detail: Betula glandulosa dominated, but not exceeding 20 cm.
flux_method_description: Plots of 1 x 1 m with 0.0445 m^2 aluminum frame.

citation_ch4: St. Pierre, K, Danielsen, B., Hermesdorf, L., D'Imperio, L., Iversen, L., Elberling, B. (2019) Drivers of net methane uptake across Greenlandic dry heath tundra landscapes. Soil Biology and Biochemistry, 138, 107605. 10.1016/j.soilbio.2019.107605
veg_detail: The vegetation at Disko Island was dominated by shrub species such as Betula nana, Vaccinium uliginosum, Salix glauca, Cassiope tetragona and Empetrum nigrum.
flux_method_description: Plots of 1 x 1 m with 0.0445 m^2 aluminum frame.

citation_ch4: St. Pierre, K, Danielsen, B., Hermesdorf, L., D'Imperio, L., Iversen, L., Elberling, B. (2019) Drivers of net methane uptake across Greenlandic dry heath tundra landscapes. Soil Biology and Biochemistry, 138, 107605. 10.1016/j.soilbio.2019.107605
veg_detail: Tundra heath at West-H was dominated by Cassiope tetragona and Empetrum nigrum, but also Salix glauca, a few Betula nana and mosses.
flux_method_description: Plots of 1 x 1 m with 0.0445 m^2 aluminum frame.

Global Change Biology, 22(8), 2818–2833. https://doi.org/10.1111/gcb.13242 || Blanc-Betes et al. Increased global warming potential of Arctic tundra exposed to projected deeper snow despite reduced C losses during the growing season (in prep)

veg_detail: The vegetation was dominated by tussock-forming sedges (Eriophorum vaginatum) and mosses (Sphagnum spp., Hylocomium splendens), with scattered distribution of deciduous (Betula nana, Salix pulchra) and evergreen (Cassiope tetragona, Rhododendron subarcticum) shrubs (Walker and others 1994; Wahren and others 2005).
flux_method_detail: Following methods described in Shaver et al (2007)

data_contributor_or_author: Jessica Plein, Donatella Zona, Rulon Clark, Kyle Arndt, Walter Oechel, and Douglas Stow
veg_detail: The major vegetation type at this site is graminoid-dominated wetlands, consisting of mosses, lichens, graminoids (grasses), and wet sedges
flux_method_description: We built a clear plexiglass acrylic chamber (Davidson et al., 2016; McEwing et al., 2015) and this chamber was placed on a metal frame positioned in the ground outside of the plots and had clear polyvinyl material weighed down by heavy metal chains to produce a seal inside the chamber. These measurements were performed in a closed loop, where tubes connected the chamber to the gas analyzer and then air was circulated back to the chamber. We positioned a small fan inside the chamber to ensure appropriate air mixing.

data_contributor_or_author: Robert Jespersen, Jeffrey Welker, Maria Vaisanen, and A Joshua Leffler
veg_detail: The main vascular plant species are Dryas integrifolia (an evergreen dwarf shrub), Salix  arctica (a deciduous shrub), and Carex  rupestris (a graminoid), that together comprise 93% of the vascular vegetative cover (Sharp and Sullivan, unpublished data).
flux_method_description: Transparent chambers were attached to 20 cm diameter PVC collars installed in the vegetated part of the experimental plots to 5 cm depth
soil_type_detail: The soils are 54%–64% sand, 33%– 38% silt, and 3%–7% clay (Sullivan et al., 2008).

veg_detail: A black spruce-dominated canopy at the lower elevations (Plots 1-13) and a deciduous-dominated canopy at the higher elevations (Plots 14-21). Ground cover varied along the transect. Plots 1-6 are lichen dominated, while plots 7-13 are completely covered by deep moss. Plots 14-21 are a mosaic of shallow moss and litter-covered bare ground. The woody evergreens Vaccinium vitis-idaea and Rhododendron groenlandicum are common across the entire transect and can grow densely. Small forbs (including Cornus unalaskensis and Geocaulon lividum) and graminoids are common but sparse. Shrubby Salix spp. can be found throughout the transect, while Betula nenana/Betula glandulosa can be found among the black spruce
flux_method_description: The clear chamber is a 50cmx50cmx50cm box with an open bottom made of acrylic sheets connected with corner braces and sealed with silicone and rubber washers. A custom-made gasket consisting of aluminum angle and foam weatherproofing tape runs along the bottom edge of the chamber, allowing it to form a seal with the collar. Inside the chamber are a fan to circulate air, a shielded air temperature sensor (ONSET HOBO® Temperature/Relative Humidity Smart Sensor) at ground level, a photosynthetic light sensor (ONSET HOBO® Photosynthetic light (PAR) Smart Sensor) at the top of the chamber, and a data logger (ONSET HOBO® H21-USB Microstation) attached to the sensors. An open-design pressure valve consisting of 6m of coiled ⅛” tubing allows the chamber pressure to equilibrate with the outside pressure, but minimizes CO2 and CH4 diffusion through the valve

Inside the chamber are a fan to circulate air, a shielded air temperature sensor (ONSET HOBO® Temperature/Relative Humidity Smart Sensor) at ground level, a photosynthetic light sensor (ONSET HOBO® Photosynthetic light (PAR) Smart Sensor) at the top of the chamber, and a data logger (ONSET HOBO® H21-USB Microstation) attached to the sensors. An open-design pressure valve consisting of 6m of coiled ⅛” tubing allows the chamber pressure to equilibrate with the outside pressure, but minimizes CO2 and CH4 diffusion through the valve

veg_detail: The study site is located in the active floodplain portion of the delta where tidally influenced sloughs dissect wet sedge and graminoid meadows.
flux_method_description: Gas measurements were made using a translucent PVC chamber 21 cm tall and 13 cm in diameter with a 4.2 cm wide flange at the base that was lined with a rubber gasket. Flux measurements were performed using the translucent chamber first to obtain a measurement of net ecosystem exchange (NEE). Once the chamber was removed from the collar following the NEE measurement, and CO2 concentration and relative humidity in the chamber returned to ambient conditions, a second measurement was performed with the chamber covered in opaque cloth to obtain a measurement of ecosystem respiration (ER). Gross primary productivity (GPP) was calculated as the difference between ER and NEE.

citation_ch4: Nykänen Hannu, Alm Jukka, Martikainen Pertti, & Silvola Jouko. (2022). Chamber flux data (CH4 , CO2) from Finland (1991 -1993) originally used in Nykänen et al. GBC, 12(1), 53 - 69, 1988, [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.6952933
veg_detail: NA
flux_method_description: Aluminium collars (60 cm x  60 cm) equipped with water grooves for gas-tight connection of the chamber (60 cm x 60 cm x 20 cm) were inserted in the soil, two collars at each site in summer 1991 and a  new collar at each site at Lakkasuo from September 1991 onward. At the natural sites having drained counterparts, chamber bases were randomly inserted in the soil 30-50 m upstream of the ditch, while at the drained sites the chambers were approximately in the middle of the 50 m wide strip

data_contributor_or_author: Marta Magnani; Ilaria Baneschi;  Mariasilvia Giamberini; Brunella Raco; Antonello Provenzale
citation_co2: Marta Magnani, Ilaria Baneschi, Mariasilvia Giamberini, Brunella Raco, & Antonello Provenzale. (2022). CO2 NEE and ER + air and soil meteorological and climate parameters in Arctic tundra, Ny Ålesund (Svalbard, NO) - summer 2019 [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5815579
veg_detail: The vegetation cover is heterogeneous, typical of the bioclimate subzone B-C77 with vascular plants constellating the matrix of mosses and lichens, and can be classified as prostrate dwarf-shrub and herbs tundra
flux_method_detail: non-steady state, closed dynamic flux chamber
flux_method_description: Fluxes were measured by the non-steady state, closed dynamic flux chamber method80 using a LI-COR LI-840 IRGA (InfraRed Gas Analyser) spectrophotometer and a circular stainless- steel collar (661 cm2 area, well within the range used for this site40,41,45) inserted into the soil just prior to the measurement (to a depth of about 2 cm) where to place the transparent chamber (10 cm height).

veg_detail: Subarctic alpine heath dominated by mosses and mix of evergreen and deciduous shrubs

veg_detail: Andromeda polifolia, Empetrum hermaphroditium, Vaccinium uliginosum, Carex vaginata, Carex rupestris, Hylocomium splendens, Sphagnum warnstorfii, Tomentypnum nitens

citation_co2: Grogan P., Illeris, L., Michelsen, A., & Jonasson, S. (2001). Respiration of recently-fixed plant carbon dominates mid-winter ecosystem CO2 production in sub-arctic heath tundra. Climatic Change, 50, 129-142.
veg_detail: Cassiope tetragona, Empetrum hermaphroditum, Vaccinium uliginosum, Betula nana, significant moss cover

citation_co2: Illeris, L., Koenig, S. M., Grogan, P., Jonasson, S., Michelsen, A., et al. (2004). Growing-Season Carbon Dioxide Flux in a Dry Subarctic Heath: Responses to Long-term Manipulations. Arctic, Antarctic, and Alpine Research, 36(4), 456463. https://doi.org/10.1657/1523-0430(2004)036[0456:GCDFIA]2.0.CO;2.
veg_detail: Dwarf shrub-dominated heath; Dominated by Cassope tetragona (1/3 of agb). Other dwarf shrubs (Empetrum hermaphroditum Hagerup, Vaccinium uliginosum L., Rhododendron lapponicum (L.) Wahlenb. and the shrub Betula nana L., and mosses are abundant beneath vascular canopy.

citation_co2: Grogan, P., Jonasson, S. (2006). Ecosystem CO2 production during winter in a Swedish subarctic region: the relative importance of climate and vegetation type. Global Change Biology, 12(8), 1479-1495. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2486.2006.01184.x
veg_detail: heath: Empetrum hermaphroditum, similar community as understorey of birch veg

citation_co2: Larsen, K. S., Grogan, P., Jonasson, S., & Michelsen, A. (2007b). Respiration and microbial dynamics in two subarctic ecosystems during winter and spring thaw: Effects of increased snow depth. Arctic Antarctic and Alpine Research, 39(2), 268-276. https://doi.org/10.1657/1523-0430(2007)39[268:RAMDIT]2.0.CO;2.
veg_detail: heath: dominant: Empetrum nigrum ssp. hermaphroditum, Vaccinium uliginosum, Vaccinium vitis-idaea, Andromeda polifolia, and Rhododendron lapponicum, other common species Arctostaphylos alpinus, Cassiope tetragona, Tofieldia pusilla, Carex vaginata, Betula nana,  various mosses

veg_detail: heath

veg_detail: mosses (433 +/- 33 g aboveground dry biomass m2 ), evergreen and deciduous dwarf shrubs (151 +/- 12 and 97 +/- 7gm2 , respectively) and graminoids (42 +/- 3gm2 ). The total below-ground plant biomass (1717 +/- 75 g m2 ) is ap- proximately twice the size of the aboveground biomass (724 +/- 33 g m2 =).

citation_co2: Alm, J., Schulman, L., Walden, J., Nyknen, H., Martikainen, P. J., et al. (1999). Carbon balance of a boreal bog during a year with an exceptionally dry summer. Ecology, 80(1), 161174. https://doi.org/10.1890/0012-9658(1999)080[0161:CBOABB]2.0.CO;2
veg_detail: Dominated by S. fuscum with S. angustifolium, S. balticum, or S. lindbergii in the few wet depressions. The hummock surfaces have 1040% cover of Rubus chamaemorus and Empetrum nigrum, together with Andromeda polifolia and Vaccinium microcarpum, which are more important close to the lawns. Some of the hummocks have up to 15% cover of Eriophorum vaginatum. The only important vascular plant in the lawns and hollows is Scheuchzeria palustris, which reaches 1015% cover in places. The peat in the study site is 200390 cm thick. The peat deposit consists of Sphagnum peat (von Post humification degree 12) down to a depth of 30 70 cm and EriophorumSphagnum peat with a humification degree of 24 between 150 and 180 cm depth

veg_detail: Homogenous Sphagnum spp. mosses as well as vascular plants. Specifically, the most commonly found moss species include S. majus (Russ.) C. Jens. on the carpets, S. lindbergii Schimp. and S. balticum (Russ.) C. Jens. on the lawns and S. fuscum(Schimp.) H. Klinggr. and S. rubellum Wils. on the hummocks. The vascular plant layer is dominated by Eriophorum vaginatum L., Trichophorum cespitosum (L.) Hartm., Vaccinium oxycoocos L., Andromeda polifolia L. and Rubus chamaemorus L. with both Carex limosa L. and Scheuchzeria palustris L. occuring more sparsely.

Mesic mixed tundra dominated by the deciduous shrub Vaccinium uliginosum, and with some other deciduous species Salix glauca, Salix herbacae, and Betula nana. Dominating evergreen shrub is Empetrum nigrum, and to a lesser extent evergreens Phyllodoce caerulea and Dryas integrafolia. Also, some forbs occur, such as Polygonum viviparum, Alchemilla glomerulans, and Sibbaldia procumbens, and graminoids Poa sp. and Carex sp.

site_name: Mackenzie Valley, Anzac, Mid-Boreal - Peat Plateau
citation_co2: Startsev, N., Bhatti, J. S., & Jassal, R. S. (2016). Surface CO2 Exchange Dynamics across a Climatic Gradient in McKenzie Valley: Effect of Landforms, Climate and Permafrost. Forests, 7(11), 279. https://doi.org/10.3390/f7110279
veg_detail: Anzac and Fort Simpson uplands were characterized by a dense Picea mariana stand with a feathermoss understorey consisting primarily of Hylocomium splendens and Pleurozium schreberi. Peat plateaus had a sparse Picea mariana canopy with Ledum groenlandicum and Vaccinium vitis-idaea dominating the shrub layer, and a ground layer of lichen species, including Cladina mitis, C. rangiferina, and C. stellaris.

site_name: Mackenzie Valley, Fort Simpson, High Boreal - Peat Plateau
citation_co2: Startsev, N., Bhatti, J. S., & Jassal, R. S. (2016). Surface CO2 Exchange Dynamics across a Climatic Gradient in McKenzie Valley: Effect of Landforms, Climate and Permafrost. Forests, 7(11), 279. https://doi.org/10.3390/f7110279
veg_detail: Anzac and Fort Simpson uplands were characterized by a dense Picea mariana stand with a feathermoss understorey consisting primarily of Hylocomium splendens and Pleurozium schreberi. Peat plateaus had a sparse Picea mariana canopy with Ledum groenlandicum and Vaccinium vitis-idaea dominating the shrub layer, and a ground layer of lichen species, including Cladina mitis, C. rangiferina, and C. stellaris.

site_name: Mackenzie Valley, Inuvik, High Sub-Arctic - Peat Plateau
citation_co2: Startsev, N., Bhatti, J. S., & Jassal, R. S. (2016). Surface CO2 Exchange Dynamics across a Climatic Gradient in McKenzie Valley: Effect of Landforms, Climate and Permafrost. Forests, 7(11), 279. https://doi.org/10.3390/f7110279
veg_detail: Inuvik dominated by an open canopy of Picea mariana with a shrub layer of Vaccinium vitis-idaea and Ledum decumbens. Petasites sp. and Rubus chamaemorus were predominant in the herbaceous layer, while Cladina mitis, Sphagnum angustifolium, Peltigera spp. and Cladonia spp. comprised the ground layer. vegetated by Ledum decumbens, Andromeda polifolia, Betula glandulosa, and Vaccinium vitis-idaea dominating the shrub layer, a herbaceous layer of Rubus chamaemorus and Carex spp., and a ground layer comprised primarily of the lichen species Flavocetraria nivalis and Cladina mitis. Collapse scars were treeless at all sites, with vegetation dominated by a moss layer of Sphagnum sp. and S. fuscum with shrub cover including Chamaedaphne calyculata and Andromeda polifolia, and a herbaceous layer of Smilacina trifolia, Eriophorum sp. and Carex sp.

site_name: Mackenzie Valley, Inuvik, High Sub-Arctic - Upland
citation_co2: Startsev, N., Bhatti, J. S., & Jassal, R. S. (2016). Surface CO2 Exchange Dynamics across a Climatic Gradient in McKenzie Valley: Effect of Landforms, Climate and Permafrost. Forests, 7(11), 279. https://doi.org/10.3390/f7110279
veg_detail: Inuvik dominated by an open canopy of Picea mariana with a shrub layer of Vaccinium vitis-idaea and Ledum decumbens. Petasites sp. and Rubus chamaemorus were predominant in the herbaceous layer, while Cladina mitis, Sphagnum angustifolium, Peltigera spp. and Cladonia spp. comprised the ground layer. vegetated by Ledum decumbens, Andromeda polifolia, Betula glandulosa, and Vaccinium vitis-idaea dominating the shrub layer, a herbaceous layer of Rubus chamaemorus and Carex spp., and a ground layer comprised primarily of the lichen species Flavocetraria nivalis and Cladina mitis. Collapse scars were treeless at all sites, with vegetation dominated by a moss layer of Sphagnum sp. and S. fuscum with shrub cover including Chamaedaphne calyculata and Andromeda polifolia, and a herbaceous layer of Smilacina trifolia, Eriophorum sp. and Carex sp.

site_name: Mackenzie Valley, Normal Wells, Low Sub-Arctic - Peat Plateau
citation_co2: Startsev, N., Bhatti, J. S., & Jassal, R. S. (2016). Surface CO2 Exchange Dynamics across a Climatic Gradient in McKenzie Valley: Effect of Landforms, Climate and Permafrost. Forests, 7(11), 279. https://doi.org/10.3390/f7110279
veg_detail: The NormanWells upland had a sparse Picea mariana canopy with Ledum groenlandicum, Arctostaphylos rubra, and Vaccinium uliginosum dominating the shrub layer, and a ground layer of primarily moss species, including Tomenthypnum nitens, Hylocomium splendens, and Aulacomnium palustre. peat plateaus were treeless, with vegetation in Norman Wells dominated by a ground layer of Cladina mitis with patches of Sphagnum fuscum. The vascular vegetation consisted of a mix of Ledum decumbens with Vaccinium vitis-idaea, Andromeda polifolia, Myrica gale, and Vaccinium uliginosum in the shrub layer, and an herbaceous layer of scattered Carex sp. and Rubus chamaemorus.

site_name: Mackenzie Valley, Norman Wells, Low Sub-Arctic - Upland
citation_co2: Startsev, N., Bhatti, J. S., & Jassal, R. S. (2016). Surface CO2 Exchange Dynamics across a Climatic Gradient in McKenzie Valley: Effect of Landforms, Climate and Permafrost. Forests, 7(11), 279. https://doi.org/10.3390/f7110279
veg_detail: The NormanWells upland had a sparse Picea mariana canopy with Ledum groenlandicum, Arctostaphylos rubra, and Vaccinium uliginosum dominating the shrub layer, and a ground layer of primarily moss species, including Tomenthypnum nitens, Hylocomium splendens, and Aulacomnium palustre. peat plateaus were treeless, with vegetation in Norman Wells dominated by a ground layer of Cladina mitis with patches of Sphagnum fuscum. The vascular vegetation consisted of a mix of Ledum decumbens with Vaccinium vitis-idaea, Andromeda polifolia, Myrica gale, and Vaccinium uliginosum in the shrub layer, and an herbaceous layer of scattered Carex sp. and Rubus chamaemorus.

citation_co2: Dyukarev, E. A., Godovnikov, E. A., Karpov, D. V., Kurakov, S. A., Lapshina, et al. (2019). Net Ecosystem Exchange, Gross Primary Production And Ecosystem Respiration In Ridge-Hollow Complex At Mukhrino Bog. Geography, Environment, Sustainability, 12(2). https://doi.org/10.24057/2071-9388-2018-77.
veg_detail: Pine bogs and ridge-hollow complexes are dominant at the boundaries of the peatbog. The veg is represented by rare pine trees and shrubs dense herbaceous veg and mosses. Tree cover is mainly represented by stunted Pinus sylvestris. The dwarf shrub layer consists of Ledum palustre, Andromeda polifolia, Chamaedaphne calyculata, Vaccinium vitis-idaea, V. uliginosum, and Oxycoccus palustris. Herbs are Rubus chamaemorus and a few tiny species of sundews (Drosera anglica, D. intermedia, D. rotundifolia). Carex limosa, Eriophorum vaginatum, Scheuchzeria palustris are widespread within area. Moss layer Sphagnum fuscum, S. lindbergii, S. balticum, S. papillosum, S. angustifolium, S. magellanicum, S. jensenii, etc.

citation_co2: Dyukarev, E. A., Godovnikov, E. A., Karpov, D. V., Kurakov, S. A., Lapshina, et al. (2019). Net Ecosystem Exchange, Gross Primary Production And Ecosystem Respiration In Ridge-Hollow Complex At Mukhrino Bog. Geography, Environment, Sustainability, 12(2). https://doi.org/10.24057/2071-9388-2018-77.
veg_detail: Pine bogs and ridge-hollow complexes are dominant at the boundaries of the peatbog. The veg is represented by rare pine trees and shrubs dense herbaceous veg and mosses. Tree cover is mainly represented by stunted Pinus sylvestris. The dwarf shrub layer consists of Ledum palustre, Andromeda polifolia, Chamaedaphne calyculata, Vaccinium vitis-idaea, V. uliginosum, and Oxycoccus palustris. Herbs are Rubus chamaemorus and a few tiny species of sundews (Drosera anglica, D. intermedia, D. rotundifolia). Carex limosa, Eriophorum vaginatum, Scheuchzeria palustris are widespread within area. Moss layer Sphagnum fuscum, S. lindbergii, S. balticum, S. papillosum, S. angustifolium, S. magellanicum, S. jensenii, etc.

data_contributor_or_author: Kerry J. Dinsmore, Julia Drewer, Peter E. Levy, Charles George, Annalea Lohila, Mika Aurela, and Ute M. Skiba
citation_ch4: Dinsmore, K. J., Drewer, J., Levy, P. E., George, C., Lohila, A., Aurela, M., and Skiba, U. M.: Growing season CH4 and N2O fluxes from a subarctic landscape in northern Finland; from chamber to landscape scale, Biogeosciences, 14, 799–815, https://doi.org/10.5194/bg-14-799-2017, 2017.
veg_detail: classified as an Uliginosum–Vaccinium–Empetrum (UVET) type Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris) forest. forest floor contains a varying degree of lichen (Cladonia spp.), which is heavily dependent on the presence/absence of reindeer
flux_method_description: Chamber lids, consisting of a 25 cm section of polypropylene pipe with a closed metal top, pressure compensation plug and draft excluder tape for sealing, were attached and sealed to the in situ bases during the 45min flux measurement period. Chamber air (100 mL) was sampled four times throughout the approximately 45 min sampling period and flushed through 20 mL glass vials sealed with butyl rubber plugs using a double needle system; vials were kept at atmospheric pressure reducing problems associated with pressure changes during transportation. Vials were returned to the laboratory at the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, Edinburgh, for analysis within approximately 1 month

data_contributor_or_author: Kerry J. Dinsmore, Julia Drewer, Peter E. Levy, Charles George, Annalea Lohila, Mika Aurela, and Ute M. Skiba
citation_co2: Dinsmore, K. J., Drewer, J., Levy, P. E., George, C., Lohila, A., Aurela, M., and Skiba, U. M.: Growing season CH4 and N2O fluxes from a subarctic landscape in northern Finland; from chamber to landscape scale, Biogeosciences, 14, 799–815, https://doi.org/10.5194/bg-14-799-2017, 2017.
citation_ch4: Dinsmore, K. J., Drewer, J., Levy, P. E., George, C., Lohila, A., Aurela, M., and Skiba, U. M.: Growing season CH4 and N2O fluxes from a subarctic landscape in northern Finland; from chamber to landscape scale, Biogeosciences, 14, 799–815, https://doi.org/10.5194/bg-14-799-2017, 2017.
veg_detail: a eutrophic fen dominated by large, treeless flarks with abundant sedge vegetation and intermittent brown moss and Sphagnum cover. Intermediate, low ridges consist of birch fen vegetation interspersed with pubescent birch trees (Betula pubescens). The most common shrubs are Betula nana, Andromeda polifolia and Vaccinium oxycoccos; herbaceous plants are primarily Potentilla palustris and Menyanthes trifoliata; and grasses are predominantly Carex species (several different species observed) or Scheuchzeria palustris.
flux_method_description: Chamber lids, consisting of a 25 cm section of polypropylene pipe with a closed metal top, pressure compensation plug and draft excluder tape for sealing, were attached and sealed to the in situ bases during the 45min flux measurement period. Chamber air (100 mL) was sampled four times throughout the approximately 45 min sampling period and flushed through 20 mL glass vials sealed with butyl rubber plugs using a double needle system; vials were kept at atmospheric pressure reducing problems associated with pressure changes during transportation. Vials were returned to the laboratory at the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, Edinburgh, for analysis within approximately 1 month

veg_detail: The forest is dominated by mountain birch though it is very open with the understorey being dominated by dwarf shrubs (Empetrum nigrum ssp. hermaphroditum L., Betula nana L. and Vaccinium vitis-idaea L.) and lichen sp.
flux_method_description: 16 cm diameter PVC collars were inserted to a depth of 5 cm.  Fluxes were calculated over a 1-h closure period, with samples being collected after 0, 20 and 60 min to check for linearity of CH4 build-up or uptake

veg_detail: In the areas immediately surrounding the mires, the birch trees are generally absent, with these areas being dominated by similar species to the forest understorey, lichens and dwarf shrubs (lichen-dominated heaths).
flux_method_description: 16 cm diameter PVC collars were inserted to a depth of 5 cm.  Fluxes were calculated over a 1-h closure period, with samples being collected after 0, 20 and 60 min to check for linearity of CH4 build-up or uptake

veg_detail: The mire lawns were dominated by floating mats of graminoids including species in the genera Eriophorum and Carex
flux_method_description: These were 20 cm deep, 31 cm diameter PVC collars that were inserted through 8 cm thick polystyrene rings (external diameter of 51 cm and an internal diameter of 31 cm), so that 5 cm of the collar projected below the float into the water or sedge mat. Fluxes were measured over a 30-min period, with samples being collected after 0, 10 and 30 min

citation_ch4: Moore, T.R., Knowles, R. Methane emissions from fen, bog and swamp peatlands in Quebec. Biogeochemistry 11, 45–61 (1990). https://doi.org/10.1007/BF00000851
veg_detail: Horizontial poor fen- Dominant vegetation is Sphagnum lindbergii and Carex limosa
flux_method_description: Polycarbonate bottles (6 per site) about 40cm high and 26cm diameter, with the base removed, were pushed about 5cm into the peat surface to ensure a seal against the ambient atmosphere; the necks were sealed with a rubber stopper, a 1Ocm glass tube and serum stopper. The bottles were moved around the site at each sampling date. Ambient atmosphere samples were collected at the time the bottles were sealed and stored in 3-mL Vacutainers (Becton-Dickinson, Rutherford, NJ). Twenty-four hours later, a 3-mL sample of the air within the chamber was withdrawn with a syringe and transferred to a Vacutainer. During the spring thaw of the peat, air in the chambers was sampled every 3 or 4d, with the chambers left in the thawing peat, with the neck sealed. The samples were sent to Montreal and analysed for methane concentrations by gas chromatography (Nelson & Knowles 1978), usually within 10d of sampling.

During the spring thaw of the peat, air in the chambers was sampled every 3 or 4d, with the chambers left in the thawing peat, with the neck sealed. The samples were sent to Montreal and analysed for methane concentrations by gas chromatography (Nelson & Knowles 1978), usually within 10d of sampling.

citation_ch4: Moore, T.R., Knowles, R. Methane emissions from fen, bog and swamp peatlands in Quebec. Biogeochemistry 11, 45–61 (1990). https://doi.org/10.1007/BF00000851
veg_detail: Northern ribbed fen-string: peat surface about 20cm above water level, dominant vegetation is Scirpus cespitosus, Chamaedaphne calycultata, Sphagnum spp., and Betula michauxii
flux_method_description: Polycarbonate bottles (6 per site) about 40cm high and 26cm diameter, with the base removed, were pushed about 5cm into the peat surface to ensure a seal against the ambient atmosphere; the necks were sealed with a rubber stopper, a 1Ocm glass tube and serum stopper. The bottles were moved around the site at each sampling date. Ambient atmosphere samples were collected at the time the bottles were sealed and stored in 3-mL Vacutainers (Becton-Dickinson, Rutherford, NJ). Twenty-four hours later, a 3-mL sample of the air within the chamber was withdrawn with a syringe and transferred to a Vacutainer. During the spring thaw of the peat, air in the chambers was sampled every 3 or 4d, with the chambers left in the thawing peat, with the neck sealed. The samples were sent to Montreal and analysed for methane concentrations by gas chromatography (Nelson & Knowles 1978), usually within 10d of sampling.

data_contributor_or_author: Terhi Riutta, Aino Korrensalo, Anna M. Laine, Jukka Laine, and Eeva-Stiina Tuittila
citation_ch4: Riutta, T., Korrensalo, A., Laine, A. M., Laine, J., and Tuittila, E.-S.: Interacting effects of vegetation components and water level on methane dynamics in a boreal fen, Biogeosciences, 17, 727–740, https://doi.org/10.5194/bg-17-727-2020, 2020.
veg_detail: Nutrient-poor oligotrophic, treeless fen, field layer is dominated by sedges and dwarf shrubs. The most abundant sedge species is Carex lasiocarpa Ehrh.. The most abundant shrubs are the deciduous Betula nana L. and ericaceous Andromeda polifolia L. and Vaccinium oxycoccos L.  The moss layer forms a continuous carpet dominated by Sphagnum papillosum Lindb.. The vegetation inventory and variation conducted at the site are described in detail in Kokkonen et al. (2019).
flux_method_description: A stainless steel collar (56 cm × 56 cm × 30 cm, length × width × height) was permanently inserted into each sample plot prior to the start of the study. The collars had a water groove to allow chamber placement and airtight sealing during the measurement. For the flux measurements, an aluminum chamber of 60 cm × 60 cm× 30 cm was placed on the water groove of the collar. After the chamber placement, a vent on the chamber roof that ensured pressure equilibration was sealed with a septum plug.  A 40 mL air sample was drawn into a polypropylene syringe at 5, 15, 25, and 35 min after closure. The samples were stored at +4 ◦C before analysis, which was carried out within 36 h

data_contributor_or_author: S.C. Whalen, W. S. Reeburgh, and K. S. Kizer
citation_ch4: Whalen, S. C.: Biogeochemistry of methane exchange between natural wetlands and the atmosphere, Environ. Eng. Sci., 22, 73–94, https://doi.org/10.1089/ees.2005.22.73, 2005.
veg_detail: Primary succession forest on river floodplain. The floodplain succession is controlled by river erosion and deposition and begins with bares and bars. These are populated with grasses and shrubs.
flux_method_description: Each chamber consists of a skirted aluminum base and lucite vertical sections and lids that utilize a water-filled channel for a seal. Bases were deployed in triplicate at all floodplain sites and at upland site UP3A. Bases at site UP1A were deployed in duplicate. Syringe samples were collected from each chamber over a 0.75-hour time course and were analyzed for CH4 in the laboratory by flame ionization detection gas chromatograph. Details are given by Whalen and Reeburgh[1988]. The minimum detectable flux depended on chamber area:volume ratios, but was usually +/- 0.2 mg CH4 m-2d-1 . Flux values below the detection limit are reported as zero.

data_contributor_or_author: S.C. Whalen, W. S. Reeburgh, and K. S. Kizer
citation_ch4: Whalen, S. C.: Biogeochemistry of methane exchange between natural wetlands and the atmosphere, Environ. Eng. Sci., 22, 73–94, https://doi.org/10.1089/ees.2005.22.73, 2005.
veg_detail: Primary succession forest on river floodplain. Fluvial deposition of silt and sand during high river stages leads to development of terraces, which are populated by alder and willow. This stage is followed by development of balsam poplar stands with an understory of white spruce.
flux_method_description: Each chamber consists of a skirted aluminum base and lucite vertical sections and lids that utilize a water-filled channel for a seal. veg_detail: Primary succession forest on river floodplain. The longer-lived evergreen spruce overtops the poplar, and an insulating feather moss layer develops. Shading by the evergreen forest and insulation provided by the moss surface lead to development of permafrost. The climax in this successional sequence is a black spruce community, which develops into a bog
flux_method_description: Each chamber consists of a skirted aluminum base and lucite vertical sections and lids that utilize a water-filled channel for a seal. Bases were deployed in triplicate at all floodplain sites and at upland site UP3A. Bases at site UP1A were deployed in duplicate. data_contributor_or_author: S.C. Whalen, W. S. Reeburgh, and K. S. Kizer
citation_ch4: Whalen, S. C.: Biogeochemistry of methane exchange between natural wetlands and the atmosphere, Environ. Eng. Sci., 22, 73–94, https://doi.org/10.1089/ees.2005.22.73, 2005.
veg_detail: Secondary succession in an upland region following fire. The upland successional sequence is fire-dominated, and progresses on micaceous loess soils through herb-shrub, hardwood, and evergreen conifer stages, all governed by longevity and overtopping. North-facing slopes receive much less radiation and are dominated by black spruce and permafrost.
flux_method_description: Each chamber consists of a skirted aluminum base and lucite vertical sections and lids that utilize a water-filled channel for a seal. Bases were deployed in triplicate at all floodplain sites and at upland site UP3A. Bases at site UP1A were deployed in duplicate. citation_ch4: Alexey R. Desyatkin, Fumiaki Takakai, Pavel P. Fedorov, Maya C. Nikolaeva, Roman V. Desyatkin & Ryusuke Hatano (2009): CH4 emission from different stages of thermokarst formation in Central Yakutia, East Siberia, Soil Science and Plant Nutrition, 55:4, 558-570
veg_detail: larch forest with mountain cranberry (Vaccinium vitis-idaea), wet grassland belt dominated by Carex orthostachys, no vegetation on pond
landform: This depression has a small pond filled with water from the thawed ice complex and run-off from the surrounding forest and grassland.
flux_method_description: transparent acryl chambers 30 cm x 30 cm x 60 cm, The time intervals of sampling were 0, 10 and 20 min after inserting the chamber onto the collar and closing the top.

data_contributor_or_author: Alexey R. Desyatkin, Fumiaki Takakai, Pavel P. Fedorov, Maya C. Nikolaeva, Roman V. Desyatkin & Ryusuke Hatano
citation_ch4: Alexey R. Desyatkin, Fumiaki Takakai, Pavel P. Fedorov, Maya C. Nikolaeva, Roman V. Desyatkin & Ryusuke Hatano (2009): CH4 emission from different stages of thermokarst formation in Central Yakutia, East Siberia, Soil Science and Plant Nutrition, 55:4, 558-570
veg_detail: larch forest with mountain cranberry (Vaccinium vitis-idaea), wet grassland belt dominated by Carex orthostachys, no vegetation on pond
landform: The grassland area in the thermokarst depression is divided into four different belts of vegetation around the pond: pond vegetation, wet grassland, middle grassland and dry grassland. Under the depression of this site, the ice-wedge complex is completely absent.
flux_method_description: transparent acryl chambers 30 cm x 30 cm x 60 cm, The time intervals of sampling were 0, 10 and 20 min after inserting the chamber onto the collar and closing the top.

landform: moist lawns in a mire complex

veg_detail: Wet/moist coastal tundra
flux_method_description: Gas fluxes were measured using two-component, mirror-polished aluminum, static flux chambers [Livingston and Hutchinson, 1995], covering a basal area of 0.264 m2 and with a headspace of 188 liters. Flask and air samples were collected during the chamber closure.

data_contributor_or_author: Marina Becher, Johan Olofsson and Jonatan Klaminder
citation_co2: Marina Becher et al 2015 Environ. Res. Lett. 10 114006
veg_detail: The studied non-sorted circles were characterized by sparsely vegetated, often circular areas surrounded by a more densely vegetated rim.
flux_method_description: We used a closed system with a CPY-2 canopy exchange chamber (PP Systems), 145mm height×164mm diameter. The chamber was sealed to the ground by attaching it to clear Perspex collars (147 mm in diameter and 90 mm high) with a connected clear vinyl skirt, which was sealed to the ground surface with a heavy tube depressing the attached skirt.Measurements were taken over a period of 2 min The chamber was reequilibrated to ambient atmospheric conditions between measurements. At each plot, we conducted flux measurements in the following order: a first measurement with an uncovered chamber enabling photosynthesis and soil respiration to occur simultaneously (i.e., NEE) after covering the chamber to exclude all light for 2 min to enable photosynthetic activity to cease; and a second measurement in dark conditions.

data_contributor_or_author: Torbern Tagesson; Department of Physical Geography and Ecosystems Science, Lund University, Sölvegatan 12, 223 62, Lund, Sweden,
citation_co2: Tagesson, T., Mölder, M., Mastepanov, M., Sigsgaard, C., Tamstorf, M.P., Lund, M., . . . Ström, L. (2012) Land-atmosphere exchange of methane from soil thawing to soil freezing in a high-Arctic wet tundra ecosystem. Global Change Biology, 18, 1928–1940.
citation_ch4: Tagesson, T., Mölder, M., Mastepanov, M., Sigsgaard, C., Tamstorf, M.P., Lund, M., . . . Ström, L. (2012) Land-atmosphere exchange of methane from soil thawing to soil freezing in a high-Arctic wet tundra ecosystem. Global Change Biology, 18, 1928–1940.
veg_detail: High-Arctic heterogeneous wetland area. It is a patterned fen characterized by alternating high, dry heath areas, and low, wet fen areas
flux_method_detail: CO2: EC_open CH4: Combination of the gradient and eddy covariance methods
flux_method_description: 3-axis sonic anemometer (Metek, Gmbh, Elmshorn,Germany), and an open-path CO2/H2O infrared gas analyzer was installed at 3.3 m above the surface. The gas analyzer was tilted 32°from vertical next to the sonic anemometer. CH4 fluxes were thus estimated by combining gradient and EC methods. The CH4 concentrations were measured at two levels (0.70 and 2.75 m) on the tower at 1 Hz rate. The system consisted of a laser off-axis integrated cavity output spectroscopy analyzer (LGR; DLT200,Fast Methane Analyzer, repeatability 1 ppb at 0.1 Hz, Los Gatos Research, Mountain View, CA, USA

citation_co2: Rautakoski, Vekuri, Korkiakoski, Ojanen, Lohila & Aurela: Effect of selection harvest on the carbon fluxes of nutrient-rich peatland forest. Planned publication, 2024
veg_detail: Tree cover: Picea abies, Betula pubescens, Pinus sylvestris. Forest floor: Vaccinum myrtillus, Vaccinum vitis-idae, Oxalis acetosella, Trientalis europae, Dryopteris carthusiana, Carex globularis. Mosses: Pleurozium schreberi, Hylocomium Splendens, Dicranum polysetum, Dicranum majus, Sphagnum girgensohnii, Sphagnum russowi. No recent changes in vegetation composition. Most abundant species is listed first and other common species after it.
flux_method_description: tower height 29m, location in the border of to-be-selection harvested area (continuous cover forestry, CCF) and control forest (no harvesting)

citation_co2: Rautakoski, Vekuri, Korkiakoski, Ojanen, Lohila & Aurela: Effect of selection harvest on the carbon fluxes of nutrient-rich peatland forest. Planned publication, 2024
veg_detail: Tree cover: Picea abies, Betula pubescens, Pinus sylvestris. Forest floor: Vaccinum myrtillus, Vaccinum vitis-idae, Oxalis acetosella, Trientalis europae, Dryopteris carthusiana, Carex globularis. Mosses: Pleurozium schreberi, Hylocomium Splendens, Dicranum polysetum, Dicranum majus, Sphagnum girgensohnii, Sphagnum russowi. No recent changes in vegetation composition. Most abundant species is listed first and other common species after it.
flux_method_description: tower height 29m, location in the border of selection harvested area (continuous cover forestry, CCF, harvesting in the end of March 2021) and control forest (no harvesting)

citation_co2: Rautakoski, Vekuri, Korkiakoski, Ojanen, Lohila & Aurela: Effect of selection harvest on the carbon fluxes of nutrient-rich peatland forest. Planned publication, 2024
veg_detail: Tree cover: Picea abies, Betula pubescens, Pinus sylvestris. Forest floor: Vaccinum myrtillus, Vaccinum vitis-idae, Oxalis acetosella, Trientalis europae, Dryopteris carthusiana, Carex globularis. Mosses: Pleurozium schreberi, Hylocomium Splendens, Dicranum polysetum, Dicranum majus, Sphagnum girgensohnii, Sphagnum russowi. No recent changes in vegetation composition. Most abundant species is listed first and other common species after it.
flux_method_description: tower height 29m, location in the border of to-be-selection harvested area (continuous cover forestry, CCF) and control forest (no harvesting)

citation_co2: Rautakoski, Vekuri, Korkiakoski, Ojanen, Lohila & Aurela: Effect of selection harvest on the carbon fluxes of nutrient-rich peatland forest. Planned publication, 2024
veg_detail: Tree cover: Picea abies, Betula pubescens. Forest floor: Vaccinum myrtillus, Vaccinum vitis-idae, Rubus idae, Oxalis acetosella, Dryopteris carthusiana, Trientalis europae, Deschampsia flexuosa, Carex globularis. Mosses: Pleurozium schreberi, Hylocomium Splendens, Dicranum polysetum, Dicranum majus, Sphagnum girgensohnii, Sphagnum russowi. Selection harvest reduced the amount of trees by 60% (basal area and number of trees). Forest floor vegetation is partly disturbed by the harvesting machine and harvesting residue covers about 10% of the forest floor area. Grasses and shrubs are getting more abundant towards the end of the summer 2023. Harvesting was done in the end of March 2021. Most abundant species is listed first and other common species after it.
flux_method_description: tower height 29m, location in the border of selection harvested area (continuous cover forestry, CCF, harvesting in the end of March 2021) and control forest (no harvesting)

veg_detail: Ridge-hollow complex: ridge (pine-shrub-sphagnum community: Pinus sylvestris, Ledum palustre, Andromeda polifolia, Sphagnum fuscum), hollow (Scheuchzeria palustris, Drosera rotundifolia, Sphagnum balticum)
landform: Ridge-hollow complex: elevated ridges and flat hollows
flux_method_description: Height of the tower and wind measurements is 4 m, horizontal separation is 15 cm

veg_detail: NA

The site lies just above the current tree line with mountain birch trees, and features typical upland tundra vegetation. The palsas are typically characterized by lichens and evergreen dwarf shrubs (Empetrum nigrum, Rhododendron tomentosum, Rubus chamaemorus, Vaccinium vitis-idaea). The shallow ponds can feature a base moss layer (Sphagnum spp.), and fen areas are dominated by sedges and cottongrass (Carex rotundata, Eriophorum scheuchzeri, Eriophorum russoleum, Eriophorum vaginatum).

veg_detail: Wet tussock tundra
flux_method_detail: Closed path analyzers were mainly used, at times when closed path analyzers was not functioning, open path data were used if available. OP (Li-7500 Licor), CP (FGGA Los Gatos)
flux_method_description: Wind is measured by USA1, Metek. Tubing length was 12.8 m. Anemometer is placed 5.11 m above the ground level

veg_detail:
Ridge-hollow patterned bogs. Pine-dwarf shrubs: Sphagnum ridges with Pinus sylvestris, Ledum palustris, Chamaedaphne calyculata, Sphagnum fuscum. The pine height is
usually 0.5–2.0 m and 3–10% cover. Sphagnum hollows (10-100 m2).  Carex limosa, Eriophorum russeolum, Scheuchzeria palustris, Sphagnum balticum, S. papillosum.

Ridge-hollow-lake patterned bogs. Pine-dwarf shrubs: Sphagnum ridges with Pinus sylvestris, Ledum palustris, Chamaedaphne calyculata, Sphagnum fuscum. The pine height is
usually 0.5–2.0 m and 3–10% cover. Sphagnum hollows (10-100 m2).  Carex limosa, Eriophorum russeolum, Scheuchzeria palustris, Sphagnum balticum, S. papillosum.
Larix gmelinii

veg_detail: NA

data_contributor_or_author: Koffi Dodji Noumonvi; Matthias Peichl; Mats.B.Nilsson
veg_detail:
The vascular plant community of
the mire consists mainly of Eriophorum vaginatum L., Trichophorum
cespitosum L. Hartm., Vaccinium oxycoccos L.,
Andromeda polifolia L., and Rubus chamaemorus L.
Sphagnum majus Russ. C. Jens is found on the bottom of the
carpets while Sphagnum balticum Russ. C. Jens dominates
the lawn. The hummocks are dominated by Sphagnum fuscum
Schimp. Klinggr. (Laine et al 2012, Nilsson et al 2008). Total
(moss + vascular plants) aboveground biomass is 141 ± 45
gm–2 (Laine et al 2012).

Collection of Abisko Stordalen Palsa Bog Swedish network data. https://doi.org/10.18160/Q6H6-B94B

Collection of Abisko Stordalen Palsa Bog Swedish network data. https://doi.org/10.18160/Q6H6-B94B
veg_detail: Eriophorum angustifolium, Spaghnum spp
landform: In order of footprint coverage: fully thawed fen, partially thawed bog and palsa
flux_method_detail: CH4: closed path eddy covariance, CO2: open-path eddy covariance
flux_method_description: Tower height 2.92 m with 3D sonic anemometer (Gill R3-50), CO2 and CH4 measurements at 2.5 m height

Schimp. Klinggr. (Laine et al 2012, Nilsson et al 2008). Total
(moss + vascular plants) aboveground biomass is 141 ± 45
gm–2 (Laine et al 2012).

citation_co2:
Jentzsch, K., Schulz, A., Pirk, N., Foken, T., Crewell, S., and Boike, J.: High levels of CO2 exchange during synoptic-scale events introduce large uncertainty into the Arctic carbon budget, Geophys. Res. Lett., 48,
e2020GL092256, https://doi.org/10.1029/2020GL092256, 2021 and https://doi.org/10.5194/amt-14-7291-2021; http://www.europe-fluxdata.eu/home/site-details?id=SJ-Blv
veg_detail:
mixture of low vascular plants (including various species of grass and sedge such as Carex spp., Deschampsia spp., Eriophorum spp., Festuca spp. and Luzula spp.), catchfly, saxifrage, willow, various other locally common species (Dryas octopetala, Oxyria digyna, Polygonum viviparum), and some unclassified species of moss and lichen (Ohtsuka et al., 2006; Uchida et al., 2006). 
barren ground and scattered vegetation. mainly non-vascular plants (40% cover) and a few vascular plants (5% cover). CAVM-Team (2005)
flux_method_description: tower height = installation hight of both gas analyzer and anemometer: 2.75 m
c_mineral: SOCC between 1000 to 29000 SOCC (excluding the natural occuring coal in the profile), see table F1 in Boike et al. 2018 (https://essd.copernicus.org/articles/10/355/2018/)

data_contributor_or_author: Park, SB; Knohl, A; Migliavacca, M; Thum, T; Vesala, T; Peltola, O; Mammarella, I; Prokushkin, A; Kolle, O; Lavric, J; Park, SS; Heimann, M
citation_co2: Park,S.-B.;Knohl,A.; Migliavacca, M.; Thum, T.; Vesala, T.; Peltola, O.; Mammarella, I.; Prokushkin, A.; Kolle, O.; Lavricˇ, J.; et al. Temperature Control of Spring CO2 Fluxes at a Coniferous Forest and a Peat Bog in Central Siberia. Atmosphere2021,12,984. https:// doi.org/10.3390/atmos12080984
veg_detail:
Coniferous forest- The dominant tree species is Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris), ranging in age from 80 to 180 years, whereas the patchy distributed regrowth Scots pine (height < 5 m) in understory is represented by younger pine trees of several age groups (40 years). The
Atmosphere2021,12,xFORPEERREmVIEaWingroundvegetationwithinthefootprintareaislichen(CladinastellarisandC4laodfi2n0a rangiferina), with patches of dwarf shrub (Vaccinium vitis-idaea).
flux_method_description: The EC system consisted of a three-dimensional ultrasonic anemometer (USA-1, Metek GmbH, Elmshorn, Germany) with integrated 55 W heating and closed-path infrared gas analyser (LI-7200, LiCor Biosciences, Lincoln, NE, USA) to measure CO2 and H2O fluxes at 20 Hz frequency. An external diaphragm vacuum pump transported air to the gas analyser with a flow rate of 13 L min−1 at ambient atmospheric pressure.

data_contributor_or_author: Park, SB; Knohl, A; Migliavacca, M; Thum, T; Vesala, T; Peltola, O; Mammarella, I; Prokushkin, A; Kolle, O; Lavric, J; Park, SS; Heimann, M
citation_co2: Park,S.-B.;Knohl,A.; Migliavacca, M.; Thum, T.; Vesala, T.; Peltola, O.; Mammarella, I.; Prokushkin, A.; Kolle, O.; Lavricˇ, J.; et al. Temperature Control of Spring CO2 Fluxes at a Coniferous Forest and a Peat Bog in Central Siberia. Atmosphere2021,12,984. https:// doi.org/10.3390/atmos12080984
land_cover: 180=Shrub or herbaceous cover, flooded, fresh/saline/brakish water
veg_detail: The landscape was covered by a pine-dwarf, shrub-sphagnum (in Siberia, called ryam), hollow-ridge complex. They had a height of 0.4–0.6 m and were covered by plant communities consisting of dwarf pine (Pinus sylvestris f. litwinowii), which dominates the trees and dwarf shrubs (Chamaedaphne calyculata)
flux_method_description: The EC system consisted of a three-dimensional ultrasonic anemometer (USA-1, Metek GmbH, Elmshorn, Germany) with integrated 55 W heating and closed-path infrared gas analyser (LI-7200, LiCor Biosciences, Lincoln, NE, USA) to measure CO2 and H2O fluxes at 20 Hz frequency. An external diaphragm vacuum pump transported air to the gas analyser with a flow rate of 13 L min−1 at ambient atmospheric pressure.

veg_detail: Evergreen Needleleaf Forests
Evergreen Needleleaf Forests

Evergreen Needleleaf Forests Spruce and deciduous tress (mainly Betula pubescens, Populus tremula, and Salix capera). Ground floor species Vaccinium myrtillus, Empetrum nigrum, Vaccinium vitis-ideaea and forest mosses Pleurozium schreberi, Hylocomium splendens, and Dicranum polysetum
Evergreen Needleleaf Forests, mainly Scots pine, some birches, Norway spruce as an understorey species
disturb_severity: High, the tree growth was increased remarkably

peatland
Tundra heath Tundra, mosses, lichen and dwarf shrubs

Evergreen Needleleaf Forest, Picea abies 84%, Betula pendula 16%, old-growth forest

The vascular plant community of
the mire consists mainly of Eriophorum vaginatum L., Trichophorum
cespitosum L. Hartm., Vaccinium oxycoccos L.,
Andromeda polifolia L., and Rubus chamaemorus L.
Sphagnum majus Russ. C. Jens is found on the bottom of the
carpets while Sphagnum balticum Russ. C. Jens dominates
the lawn. The hummocks are dominated by Sphagnum fuscum
Schimp. Klinggr. (Laine et al 2012, Nilsson et al 2008). Total
(moss + vascular plants) aboveground biomass is 141 ± 45
gm–2 (Laine et al 2012).

Andromeda polifolia L., and Rubus chamaemorus L.
Sphagnum majus Russ. C. Jens is found on the bottom of the
carpets while Sphagnum balticum Russ. C. Jens dominates
the lawn. The hummocks are dominated by Sphagnum fuscum
Schimp. Klinggr. (Laine et al 2012, Nilsson et al 2008). Total
(moss + vascular plants) aboveground biomass is 141 ± 45
gm–2 (Laine et al 2012).

site_name: NEON Caribou Creek - Poker Flats Watershed (BONA)
veg_detail: The BONA area contains areas of permafrost, hardwood forest, wetlands, and shrublands. Moss covers patches of permafrost throughout the Caribou-Poker Creeks Research Watershed area. The hydrology and drainage of the area influences dominant vegetation types, with areas of poor drainage dominated by moss, sedge, and shrub species. Evergreen forest constitutes the majority of land area within the site. Black spruce (Picea mariana), lingonberry (Vaccinium vitis-idaea), and bog Labrador tea (Ledum groenlandicum) are some dominant species

citation_co2: Lund, M., Bjerke, J. W., Drake, B. G., Engelsen, O., Hansen, G. H., et al. (2015). Low impact of dry conditions on the CO2 exchange of a Northern-Norwegian blanket bog. Environmental Research Letters, 10(2). https://doi.org/10.1088/1748-9326/10/2/025004.
veg_detail: Permanent Wetlands, ombotrophic bogs, hollows are present between hummocks. Hummocks are characterized by dwarf shrubs (Empetrum nigrum, Vaccinium uliginosum, Calluna vulgaris, Rubus chamaemorus) with a mean height of less than 0.5m, mosses (Dicranum scoparium, Hylocomium splendens, Pleurozium schreberi, Racomitrium lanugionsum, Sphagnum spp.) and lichens (Cladonia spp.) In hollows, Sphagnum mosses (S. fuscum, S. warnstorfii, S. magellanicum, S. cuspidatum) and sedges (Carex rariflora) dominated. The cover of cryptogams (lichens and bryophytes/mosses) was almost twice as high as the cover of vascular plants (76% versus 44%), whire lichens covered on average 41% of the hummocks.

citation_co2: Lund, M., Bjerke, J. W., Drake, B. G., Engelsen, O., Hansen, G. H., et al. (2015). Low impact of dry conditions on the CO2 exchange of a Northern-Norwegian blanket bog. Environmental Research Letters, 10(2). https://doi.org/10.1088/1748-9326/10/2/025004.

The cover of cryptogams (lichens and bryophytes/mosses) was almost twice as high as the cover of vascular plants (76% versus 44%), whire lichens covered on average 41% of the hummocks.

veg_detail: Meadow Wetland Sedge/grass, moss meadow wetlands consisting of Carex spp., Eriophorum spp. Bryophytes, and graminoids
soil_type_detail: Common horizon sequence: C, Cg, Cz  These Static Cryosols have a relatively high degree of base saturation, as indicated by their pH, and thick (>15 cm) organic (peaty) horizons in the Upper 1 m of the solum. They are identified by the following properties: 1. These soils have a continuous surface organic horizon (0, H) ranging in thickness from ~15 to 40 cm. 2. These soils have Bm horizons that are continuous over the imperfectly to well-drained part of the pedon. 3. These soils have a pH (0.01 M CaC12) of 5.5 or greater in some or a11 of the B horizons. 4. The surface horizons are not strongly gleyed, but there is usually a gleyed horizon immediately above the permafrost table.

citation_co2: Emmerton, C. A., St. Louis, V. L., Humphreys, E. R., Gamon, J. A., Barker, J. D., et al. (2016). Net ecosystem exchange of CO 2 with rapidly changing high Arctic landscapes. Global Change Biology, 22(3), 11851200. https://doi.org/10.1111/gcb.13064.

These soils have Bm horizons that are continuous over the imperfectly to well-drained part of the pedon. 3. These soils have a pH (0.01 M CaC12) of 5.5 or greater in some or a11 of the B horizons. 4. site_name: NEON Caribou Creek - Poker Flats Watershed (BONA)
veg_detail: The BONA area contains areas of permafrost, hardwood forest, wetlands, and shrublands. Moss covers patches of permafrost throughout the Caribou-Poker Creeks Research Watershed area. The hydrology and drainage of the area influences dominant vegetation types, with areas of poor drainage dominated by moss, sedge, and shrub species. Evergreen forest constitutes the majority of land area within the site. Black spruce (Picea mariana), lingonberry (Vaccinium vitis-idaea), and bog Labrador tea (Ledum groenlandicum) are some dominant species
